1 coastguard ship
1 torpedo boat | casualties1 = none | casualties2 = none }} {{Campaignbox Spanish Civil War}} The '''Convoy de la victoria''' (English: "convoy of victory") is the name given by the [[Francoist Spain|Spanish Nationalist]]s to a naval battle which took place on 5 August 1936 in the [[Strait of Gibraltar]] during the [[Spanish Civil War]] between the escort of a Nationalist convoy and the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republican]] destroyer [[Churruca class destroyer|''Alcalá Galiano'']]. ==Background== At the end of July 1936, the Spanish rebel forces were in dire straits. The Republic held two-thirds of the country, the capital city, the gold reserves, the major urban centers and most of the industries. Furthermore, the main shock force of the rebels, the [[Spanish Army of Africa]], was isolated in Spanish Morocco, the Republic held most of the Navy, and from 19 July [[Spanish Republican Navy]] warships were patrolling the waters between Morocco and the mainland. Nevertheless, with the assistance of [[Nazi Germany]] and [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Fascist Italy]], the Nationalists managed to airlift their troops from Africa to [[Andalusia]].Graham, Helen. (2005). ''The Spanish Civil War. A very short introduction,.'' Oxford University Press.p.24 ===The airlift of troops=== The Nationalists requested and received transport aircraft from Germany and Italy in order to transport their troops, establishing the first airlift of troops in history. Germany sent 20 [[Junkers Ju-52]] and, between 29 July and 5 August, the Nationalists carried 1,500 men of the Spanish Army of Africa across the Strait by air, and another 15,000 between 5 and 15 AugustPreston Paul. (2006). ''The Spanish Civil War. Reaction, Revolution & Revenge.'' Harper Perennial. p.119 (according to historian [[Hugh Thomas (writer)|Hugh Thomas]], 12,000 men were flown between August and September). Hitler said that: "Franco ought to erect a monument to the glory of the Junkers-52".Thomas, Hugh. (2001). ''The Spanish Civil War.'' Penguin Books. London. p.357. This success was a major psychological blow (the news of the arrival of the Moors spread terror among the Republicans), but the Republican Navy still controlled the Straits and the Republican battleship ''[[Spanish battleship Jaime I|Jaime I]]'' threatened the transport aircraft with her heavy anti-aircraft fire.Jackson, Gabriel. (1967). The Spanish Republic and the Civil War, 1936–1939. Princeton University Press. Princeton. p. 249 ==Convoy de la Victoria== On 5 August, Franco decided to break the Republican naval blockade, with a convoy of merchant ships, carrying 2,500Beevor, Antony. (2006). ''The Battle for Spain. The Spanish Civil War, 1936–1939.'' Penguin Books. London. p.73 to 3,000 soldiers,Preston, Paul. ''Franco.'' Harper Collins. London. 1994. p. 162 equipment and heavy weapons. The convoy departed from [[Ceuta]] and was made up of four transports escorted by the gunboat ''Dato'', the coastguard ship ''Uad Kert'' (a World War I [[armed trawler]], ex-HMT ''Rother'') and the old T-1 class torpedo boat ''T-19''. The convoy was covered by five Savoia [[Savoia-Marchetti SM.81|SM.81 bombers]], three trimotors [[Fokker F.VII|Fokker]], one [[DC-2]], 2 [[Nieuport-Delage NiD 52|Nieuport]] fighters, two [[Dornier Do J|hydroplanes]] and a squadron of [[Breguet XIX]].Thomas, Hugh. (2001). The Spanish Civil War. Penguin Books. London. pp.357–358 Three Republican destroyers were keeping a close watch on [[Spanish Morocco]] ports, but in the morning of 5 August the Nationalist aircraft launched air attacks against the Republican vessels in the Strait and the Republican destroyer {{ship|Spanish destroyer|Lepanto||2}} was forced to leave Gibraltar by the British authorities.Preston, Paul. ''Franco.'' Harper Collins. London. 1994. p. 161. Because of this, only ''Alcalá Galiano'' engaged the Nationalist ships. The convoy, bound for [[Algeciras]], reached its destination on the evening after a brief exchange of fire. While mooring in Algeciras, the gunboat ''Dato'' straddled the British destroyer {{HMS|Basilisk|H11|6}} after misidentifying her as Republican.Moreno de Alborán y de Reyna, Fernando (1998) ''La guerra silenciosa y silenciada: Historia de la campaña naval durante la guerra de 1936–39''. Gráficas Lormo, p. 700. ISBN 84-923691-1-6 {{es icon}} While steaming back to [[Málaga]], ''Alcalá Galiano'' was attacked and hit by Nationalist aircraft. Francoist sources claim that she suffered 18 seamen killed and 28 wounded.Alpert, Michael (2008). ''La guerra civil española en el mar''. pp. 99–100. ISBN 84-8432-975-5 {{es icon}}{{cite book|last1=Balfour|first1=Sebastian|last2=Preston|first2=Paul|title=Spain and the great powers in the twentieth century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WcpDYhAteAgC&pg=RA1-PA171|accessdate=25 July 2011|year=1999|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-18078-8|page=1}} ==Aftermath== From 6 August transport ships crossed the Strait of Gibraltar, with the cover of Italian bombers. On 7 August, the battleship ''Jaime I'' and the cruiser ''[[Almirante Cervera class cruiser|Libertad]]'' shelled Algeciras and severely damaged ''Dato'' and ''Uad Kert''. However, in the first week of August, a German Junkers Ju 52 struck the Republican ''Jaime I'' and Italian bombers started to harass the Republican fleet so that they could no longer prevent the passage of transport ships. Furthermore, the Republican warships were inefficiently handled by their crews and two German cruisers,Deutschland class cruiser {{ship|German cruiser|Deutschland||2}} and {{ship|German cruiser|Admiral Scheer||2}} patrolled the Strait. In addition, the English authorities in Gibraltar and [[Tangier]] were hostile to the Republic. The British oil companies in Gibraltar refused to sell fuel to the Republican navy. The Tangier International Commission denied the use of the harbor to the Republican Navy, because this was contrary to the city's neutrality, but nevertheless authorized the passage of food, goods and gasoline for the German transport planes to Spanish Morocco.Jackson, Gabriel. (1967). ''The Spanish Republic and the Civil War, 1936–1939.'' Princeton University Press. Princeton. pp. 249–250 By the end of September, the Republic had lost control of the waters between Morocco and the mainland after the [[battle of Cape Espartel]].[http://www.kbismarck.org/canarias2.html KBismarck.org: "The Turning point at sea, 29 November 1936"].
